case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. the assessee

facts.text: The relevant assessment year was 1942-43.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant assessment year was 1942-43. The proceedings under section 34 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, were initiated with the issue of a notice on July 25, 1949.

facts.text: Proceedings under section 34 initiated with notice on July 25, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The proceedings under section 34 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, were initiated with the issue of a notice on July 25, 1949. The assessees contention was that the initiation of proceedings on July 25, 1949, was invalid

facts.text: Assessee's contention that initiation on July 25, 1949 was invalid due to 4-year limitation expired on March 31, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The assessees contention was that the initiation of proceedings on July 25, 1949, was invalid as the departments right to revive the assessment was governed by the old section 34 where the period of limitation prescribed was only four years in the case of failure to file a return and this period having expired on March 31, 1947

facts.text: Amending Act of 1948 (XLVIII of 1948) came into force on March 30, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: , and the Amending Act of 1948  XLVIII of 1948  having come into force on March 30, 1948, the eight years period provided therein could not be invoked.

facts.text: High Court upheld assessee's contention and held new 8-year limitation does not apply.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court upheld this contention and said In our opinion, the contention of the learned counsel for the assessee is well founded, that the new rule of limitation of eight years prescribed by the amended section 34 would not apply to the case of the assessee before us, whose was an instance of a failure to submit a return, when the period of limitation of four years had run out long before 30th March, 1948

facts.text: Appellant is Commissioner of Income-tax, respondent is assessee, assessment year 1942-43.

anchor.surface_text: KAPUR J. - This is an appeal against the judgment and order of the High Court of Madras. The appellant is the Commissioner of Income-tax and the respondent is the assessee and the year of assessment is 1942-43.

facts.text: Respondent is wife of Sheikh Abdul Khader who resided in Bangkok from September 1940 to July 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is the wife of one Sheikh Abdul Khader who was residing abroad in Bangkok from September, 1940, to July, 1947. During that period he remitted monies in the name of his agent for payment to the respondent.

facts.text: In account year, aggregate remitted Rs. 9,180.

anchor.surface_text: In the account year the aggregate amount so remitted was Rs. 9,180.

facts.text: Respondent submitted no return of her income.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent submitted no return of her income as she was bound to do and the amount became taxable under section 4(2) of the Income-tax Act

facts.text: Amount Rs. 9,180 taxable under section 4(2).

anchor.surface_text: and the amount became taxable under section 4(2) of the Income-tax Act, hereinafter referred to as the Act.

facts.text: In 1949, ITO issued notice under s.34 as amended by 1948 Act on definite information.

anchor.surface_text: In 1949 the Income-tax Officer on receipt of definite information that such income had escaped assessment issued a notice under section 34 of the Act as amended by the Amending Act of 1948

facts.text: Assessment confirmed by Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: and an appeal was taken to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner by the assessment was confirmed.

facts.text: Appeal to Income-tax Appellate Tribunal Madras unsuccessful.

anchor.surface_text: A further appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal Madras, was also unsuccessful.

facts.text: Reference to High Court: question on validity of notice July 25, 1949 for Rs.9180 escaped by failure to submit return.

anchor.surface_text: The reference was thereupon made to the High Court and one of the questions referred was Whether the proceedings under section 34 of the Indian Income-tax Act initiated on 25th July, 1949, to assess the amount of Rs. 9,180 which escaped assessment during the year 1942-43 by failure to submit a voluntary return are valid in la ?

facts.text: High Court held 8-year limitation not applicable as 4 years expired before March 30, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: It was held that the limitation of eight years prescribed by section 34 as amended by the Amending Act of 1948 did not apply to the case of assessee which was a case of failure to submit the return and the period four years had expired before March 30, 1948, when the amendment in section 34 was made by the Amending Act of 1948.

facts.text: High Court held section 31 of 1953 Act not applicable.

anchor.surface_text: It was also held that section 31 of the Amending Act of 1953 was not applicable and the question was therefore answered in the negative.

facts.text: In 1941-42, assessee received Rs. 9,180 from husband in Siam.

anchor.surface_text: SARKAR J. - The respondent in this appeal is the assessee. She is the wife of one Sheikh Abdul Khader who lived in Siam. In the year 1941-42, she received from her husband from Siam a sum of Rs. 9,180.

facts.text: Rs. 9,180 constituted income under s.4(2), not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed that this amount constituted Income in her hands within section 4(2) of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

facts.text: Assessee submitted no return.

anchor.surface_text: She did not however submit any return in respect of it.

facts.text: Notice under s.34 issued July 25, 1949; assessed October 24, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: On July 25, 1949, a notice under section 34 of the Act was issued to her asking her to file a return. Thereafter, she was assessed on therefore income on October 24, 1949.

facts.text: Appeal from assessment unsuccessful.

anchor.surface_text: She appealed from that order but was unsuccessful in having the assessment set aside.

facts.text: Under old s.34, time expired March 31, 1947 (4 years after 1942-43).

anchor.surface_text: It is not in dispute that under section 34, as it stood before the amendment, the time to issue the notice calling for a return and to make the assessment in this case had expired on March 31, 1947

facts.text: Under amended s.34 (1948), time till March 31, 1951 (8 years).

anchor.surface_text: that is, on expiry of four years after the year in which the escaped income was first assessable, namely, 1942-43. It is not is dispute either that under section 34, as it stood after the amendment in 1948, the notice could be served and an assessment made within eight years from the end of that year, that is, in this case, within March 31, 1951.

facts.text: Income-tax and Business Profits Tax Amendment Act, 1948 passed September 8, 1948, s.34 amendment retrospective from March 30, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: This section was amended by the Income-tax and Business Profits Tax  Amendment  Act, 1948. This Act was on September 8, 1948, but the section which amended Section 34 of the Income-tax Act was brought into force retrospectively from March 30, 1948.

facts.text: Income-tax Amendment Act, 1953 (XXV of 1953) passed May 24, 1953, retrospective from April 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Now, on May 24, 1953, was passed the Income-tax  Amendment  Act, 1953,  XXV of 1953 , which was brought into force retrospectively from April 1, 1952.

facts.text: DAS, KAPUR AND SARKAR JJ. delivered separate judgments.

anchor.surface_text: DAS, KAPUR AND SARKAR JJ. delivered separate judgments. HIDAYATULLAH and RAGHUBAR DAYAL JJ. dealt with this appeal in their judgment in S. C. Prashar v. Vasantsen Dwarkadas .

facts.text: Appeal governed by S.C. Prashar v. Vasantsen Dwarkadas.

anchor.surface_text: This case is governed by the decision in C. A. No. 705/57  S. C. Prashar v. Vasantsen Dwarkadas , the judgment in which has been delivered today.

facts.text: High Court of Madras.

anchor.surface_text: KAPUR J. - This is an appeal against the judgment and order of the High Court of Madras.

facts.text: Certificate granted by High Court on condition appellant pays costs in any event.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was granted the certificate by the High Court expressly on the condition that he would pay the costs of this appeal in any event to which he had agreed.

facts.text: Appeal allowed by majority.

anchor.surface_text: BY THE COURT - In accordance with the opinion of the majority, the appeal is allowed.

anchor.surface_text: The assessees companytention was that the initiation of proceedings on July 25, 1949, was invalid as the departments right to revive the assessment was governed by the old section 34 where the period of limitation prescribed was only four years in the case of failure to file a return and this period having expired on March 31, 1947, and the Amending Act of 1948  XLVIII of 1948  having companye into force on March 30, 1948, the eight years period provided therein companyld number be invoked.

arguments.court_reasoning: Section 31 of 1953 Act deems amended s.34 always applied to proceedings after Sept 8 1948 for pre-Apr 1 1948 years, validates even if old limitation expired

arguments.claim: New 8-year limitation under amended s.34 does not apply to failure to file return where 4-year period expired before March 30, 1948

arguments.court_reasoning: S.31 declares subs (1)(2)(3) s.34 apply and deemed always applied to post-Sept 8 1948 proceedings for pre-1948 years

arguments.claim: Case governed by Prashar v. Vasantsen Dwarkadas; appeal dismissed

anchor.surface_text: This case is governed by the decision in C. A. No. 705/57  S. C. Prashar v. Vasantsen Dwarkadas , the judgment in which has been delivered today. The appeal is therefore dismissed with companyts.

arguments.claim: Amended s.34 (1948) applicable to notice and assessment as proceedings commenced after repeal

anchor.surface_text: This section was amended by the Income-tax and Business Profits Tax  Amendment  Act, 1948. This Act was on September 8, 1948, but the section which amended Section 34 of the Income-tax Act was brought into force retrospectively from March 30, 1948.

arguments.claim: Section 31 of 1953 Act applies amended s.34(1)(2)(3) deemed always to have applied to proceedings commenced after Sept 8 1948 for years ending before Apr 1 1948; validates notices/assessments

anchor.surface_text: Now, on May 24, 1953, was passed the Income-tax  Amendment  Act, 1953,  XXV of 1953 , which was brought into force retrospectively from April 1, 1952. This Act companytained a section, namely, section 31, which in my mind makes section 34 as amended by the 1948 Amending Act, applicable to the proceedings in this case.

arguments.claim: Pre-existing s.34 repealed by 1948 Act cannot apply to post-repeal proceedings; s.31 removes doubt by applying amended s.34 retrospectively

anchor.surface_text: the Amending Act of 1948 was passed on September 8, 1948, but it was given retrospective effect from March 30, 1948. It may be stated that the Amending Act repealed the existing section 34 of the principal Act and substituted for it a new section.

arguments.claim: Legislature has power to give retrospective effect to s.34 amended 1948 to revive expired limitations; s.31 does so plainly without restriction to non-barred cases

anchor.surface_text: The legislature had undoubtedly the power to make section 34 as amended in 1948 apply to an assessment for 1942-43 by giving it a retrospective operation in spite of the time to issue a numberice and to make an assessment fixed by the pre-existing law having expired before the amendment came into effect.

arguments.claim: Notice and assessment valid under amended s.34 as within 8 years and proceedings after Sept 8 1948

anchor.surface_text: Now the numberice and assessment in the present case satisfy all these companyditions. To them, therefore, section 34 as amended in 1948 applies. Judged by that section, admittedly the numberice and assessment order are unexceptionable.
BY THE COURT - In accordance with the opinion of the majority, the appeal is allowed.

holdings.text: Section 31 of the 1953 Act makes the provisions of sub-sections (1), (2) and (3) of section 34 of the principal Act apply and be deemed always to have applied to assessment proceedings commenced after September 8, 1948 for years ending before April 1, 1948

anchor.surface_text: provisions of sub-sections (1), (2) and (3) of section 34 of the principal Act shall apply and shall be deemed always to have applied

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.31 for removal of doubts; repeal of old s.34 by 1948 Act means amended s.34 governs post-repeal proceedings; retrospective deeming validates

holdings.text: The notice issued and assessment order made in this case are valid under section 34 as amended in 1948
holdings.reasoning_summary: Notice issued July 25, 1949 and assessment Oct 24, 1949 within 8-year limit under amended s.34; proceedings after Sept 8, 1948 for 1942-43 year; s.31 deems applicable despite old 4-year bar

holdings.text: The legislature had power to give retrospective effect to amended section 34 reviving time-barred assessments

anchor.surface_text: The legislature had undoubtedly the power to make section 34 as amended in 1948 apply to an assessment for 1942-43 by giving it a retrospective operation in spite of the time to issue a notice and to make an assessment fixed by the pre-existing law having expired before the amendment came into effect.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No constitutional bar to retrospective validation of limitation periods; s.31 plainly does so without limiting to non-expired cases

holdings.text: The High Court should have answered the question in the affirmative
holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of s.31 deems amended s.34 applicable, notice and assessment comply with its terms

holdings.text: In accordance with the opinion of the majority, the appeal is allowed

anchor.surface_text: BY THE COURT - In accordance with the opinion of the majority, the appeal is allowed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Majority holds proceedings valid reversing High Court

holdings.text: The High Court correctly answered the question referred to it
